Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Examining Evidence for Phenotypic and Genetic Convergence in the Guppy (Poecilia reticulata)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Convergent evolution refers to the origin of similar traits in different species, such as flight in birds, bats, and insects. It is often thought that the genes underlying convergent evolution within species are similar, but this is still an open question. This proposal uses a nucleic acid sequencing method to which genes are turned on or off at any time. This information is then compared with tail color patterns of guppies. Tail coloration is highly variable trait and plays a key role in mating displays. The project will identify color genes in different fish at different locations to understand if the same genetic signatures result in similar patterns. The study will advance scientific knowledge by answering questions concerning the predictability of evolution, and will provide research opportunities for undergraduates at one of the most ethnically diverse universities in the nation.

This proposal focuses on convergent evolution. Specifically, the researchers address two questions: 1) How similar are visible color patterns among individuals from genetically diverged populations? and 2) Will genes differentiating extreme color patterns within a population be convergent among individuals from genetically diverged sites, and if so, which ones? For the first question, the researchers will analyze photographs of male guppies from five sites and sort the patterns into color categories. The researchers hypothesize that there will be convergence in the color patterns of males from genetically diverged populations. The second question will be answered using next generation DNA sequencing. For each of the five sites, tissues from males with colored and uncolored tails will be sequenced. The differentially expressed genes between tail color types at one site will be compared to the differentially expressed genes between tail color types at the other sites to test for convergence. The researchers will be able to determine if phenotypic convergence is correlated with expression of the same genes, different genes within the same pathway, or different pathways.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching question we addressed regarded the repeatability of a trait and its associated genetics. We answered this question by examining the convergent evolution of guppy male tail ornamental coloration. We first performed a phenotypic study to compare tail color patterns. The goal was to demonstrate whether coloration was similar between independent locations. Then, we took a directed genetic approach to examining molecular convergent evolution by selecting individuals with similar color patterns at those same locations and asking whether the associated genetics were the same.

 

Major activities:

            The phenotypic and genetic data collections proposed in the original project were successfully completed. During Summer 2017, co-PI Dick traveled to Trinidad to begin the phenotypic assessment of color pattern similarity among locations. With the aid of interns associated with other research projects, she visited five guppy locations and captured a haphazard sampling of males. They then anesthetized, photographed, and released the males into their native streams after recovery. Dick created a technique for categorizing the whole color pattern. This required examination of the photographs to find unique color pattern elements that could be reliably distinguished from other elements. She used statistical analyses to examine color pattern similarity among all the sites.

             During Summer and early Fall 2017, Dick had RNA libraries prepared and sequenced for the genetic component of the study. Dick also recruited a female undergraduate student to help with this part of the study. Dick led a one-on-one journal club to educate the student on RNA-sequencing methods and guppy color evolution. They analyzed the data using the high performance computing center at the University of California-Riverside. Their goal was to characterize differential gene expression among color morphs across multiple locations.

 

Impacts:

            In cases of intraspecific convergence, it is assumed that the genetic changes underlying convergence are similar. However, it is still an open question as to whether this is the case. The proposed research makes it possible to answer questions such as: Is convergent evolution of the same phenotypic trait associated with convergent gene expression? Is phenotypic convergence correlated with expression of the same genes, different genes within the same pathway, or different pathways? Fundamentally, this research examines the predictability of evolution. In addition, this research can contribute to the understanding of phenotypic evolution. For example, finding molecular convergence could indicate that the phenotypes are constrained to evolve along certain directions while a lack of molecular convergence could indicate that the same phenotype can be produced using many-to-one mapping.

 

Results dissemination:

Co-PI Dick has submitted the photographs to FigShare to make them publicly available (DOI 10.6084/m9.figshare.5868726). The raw RNA-seq reads have been deposited into NCBI’s Sequence Read Archive Database so that any researcher may utilize the sequencing data (accession SRP126780).
